texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: author: Major Hayden date: '2022-11-27' summary: Simplify your i3 configuration and monitor sound levels with volumeicon in your tray with the i3 window manager. 🔈 tags:
texts.text: author: Major Hayden date: '2022-11-27' summary: Simplify your i3 configuration and monitor sound levels with volumeicon in your tray with the i3 window manager. 🔈 tags:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: i3
texts.text: i3

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: sound
texts.text: sound

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now that  Fedora 37  launched, I decided to wipe my main laptop and do a clean installation. I made some poor configuration choices while in a hurry over the past year and the mess finally caught up with me.
texts.text: Now that  Fedora 37  launched, I decided to wipe my main laptop and do a clean installation. I made some poor configuration choices while in a hurry over the past year and the mess finally caught up with me.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The latest version of the  i3 spin  caught my eye and I used it for the installation. Once my laptop booted up, I noticed a volume icon in my system tray that appeared automatically. I've normally used  pasystray  for this task, but  volumeicon  came with the i3 spin.
texts.text: The latest version of the  i3 spin  caught my eye and I used it for the installation. Once my laptop booted up, I noticed a volume icon in my system tray that appeared automatically. I've normally used  pasystray  for this task, but  volumeicon  came with the i3 spin.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The volumeicon tray icon has a few handy features:
texts.text: The volumeicon tray icon has a few handy features:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Notifications via libnotify (or GTK) when something sound-related changes
texts.text: Notifications via libnotify (or GTK) when something sound-related changes

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Quick access to muting and unmuting a sound device via clicking the icon
texts.text: Quick access to muting and unmuting a sound device via clicking the icon

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Access to sound mixers and preferences via a right click
texts.text: Access to sound mixers and preferences via a right click

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, it also catches key presses from my volume keys on my laptop. Catching the volume keys is disabled by default but you can change that via its configuration file.
texts.text: However, it also catches key presses from my volume keys on my laptop. Catching the volume keys is disabled by default but you can change that via its configuration file.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Normally, I would have an i3 configuration snippet like this one:
texts.text: Normally, I would have an i3 configuration snippet like this one:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Use pactl to adjust volume in PulseAudio.
set $refresh_i3status killall -SIGUSR1 i3status
bindsym XF86AudioRaiseVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-volume @DEFAULT_SINK@ +10% && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioLowerVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-volume @DEFAULT_SINK@ -10% && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioMute exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-mute @DEFAULT_SINK@ toggle && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioMicMute exec --no-startup-id pactl set-source-mute @DEFAULT_SOURCE@ toggle && $refresh_i3status
texts.text:
# Use pactl to adjust volume in PulseAudio.
set $refresh_i3status killall -SIGUSR1 i3status
bindsym XF86AudioRaiseVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-volume @DEFAULT_SINK@ +10% && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioLowerVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-volume @DEFAULT_SINK@ -10% && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioMute exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-mute @DEFAULT_SINK@ toggle && $refresh_i3status
bindsym XF86AudioMicMute exec --no-startup-id pactl set-source-mute @DEFAULT_SOURCE@ toggle && $refresh_i3status

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That works fine, but volumeicon can handle this for us. Here's my current volumeicon configuration in
texts.text: That works fine, but volumeicon can handle this for us. Here's my current volumeicon configuration in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/.config/volumeicon/volumeicon
texts.text: ~/.config/volumeicon/volumeicon

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[Alsa]
card=default

[Notification]
show_notification=true
notification_type=0

[StatusIcon]
stepsize=5
onclick=pavucontrol
theme=Default
use_panel_specific_icons=false
lmb_slider=false
mmb_mute=false
use_horizontal_slider=false
show_sound_level=true
use_transparent_background=false

[Hotkeys]
up_enabled=true
down_enabled=true
mute_enabled=true
up=XF86AudioRaiseVolume
down=XF86AudioLowerVolume
mute=XF86AudioMute
texts.text:
[Alsa]
card=default

[Notification]
show_notification=true
notification_type=0

[StatusIcon]
stepsize=5
onclick=pavucontrol
theme=Default
use_panel_specific_icons=false
lmb_slider=false
mmb_mute=false
use_horizontal_slider=false
show_sound_level=true
use_transparent_background=false

[Hotkeys]
up_enabled=true
down_enabled=true
mute_enabled=true
up=XF86AudioRaiseVolume
down=XF86AudioLowerVolume
mute=XF86AudioMute

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've changed a few things from the defaults:
texts.text: I've changed a few things from the defaults:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Enabled notifications via GTK
texts.text: Enabled notifications via GTK

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Enabled the volume keys in the
texts.text: Enabled the volume keys in the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: i3 takes care of starting the icon for me with
texts.text: i3 takes care of starting the icon for me with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec
texts.text: exec

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec --no-startup-id volumeicon
texts.text: exec --no-startup-id volumeicon

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Log out and log in again to test the changes.
texts.text: Log out and log in again to test the changes.
